course_description: Beginning with "strange arithmetics" connected to paper-flipping, clocks, and braids; ending with the shocking "Abel's Impossibility Theorem"; and filling all points between with unexpected (but surprisingly natural) connections between and motivations behind mathematical ideas students might otherwise have thought routine - this course revisits familiar ideas from precalculus, but from radically different directions than likely seen before (e.g., complex numbers birthing trigonometry; solving general cubic and quartic equations; hyperbolic trigonometry motivating logarithms; and much more!)
